comments.commentBody: Or the "Tea Party" folks.

Yea, there's a good idea Republicans, Follow Walker, ignore the Public.

Stupid is as Stupid does, Scottie.
My Dear Mr ChristoFrey ... Allow me to suggest that you read and reflect on the Tenth Amendment to the U.S. Consitution.
I live in WI. Walker is lying. The budget is facing a SHORTFALL. People are not working. WI is like 48th in new businesses. Scotty is full of it as usual.
Sanctuary cities and states anyone? ... States' Rights anyone?

Turning groups of people into "the Other" just because you don't agree with them is a sad tactic but unfortunately it works. You just dismissed your fellow Americans, citizens, voters, into something dismissive, just "protesters" to be ignored. Well, this cuts both ways sir. I have now come to view "all you Republicans" as Deplorables. You will see what happens in 2018 after ignoring us and making us angrier. Angry protesters vote.
Walker has been dividing Wisconsinites his entire career. It's how he made his bones here. He has always been a Deplorable.

Yeah, we're just citizens, Walker. Who cares about us?

Oh, and I'm waiting for the paycheck for protesting.....and waiting....and waiting.

Let us eat cake, right?
How does a man like this get elected to any political office?  I assume the NYTimes publishes Walker's nonsense to let it readers witness how dangerous the republican party is.
Because Corporations are people, people with more free speech, aka CASH, than real people.
Nice gasping attempt to cling to relevancy Mr Walker. Your self-aggrandizing puts you in fine company with your party's "leader."
Walker's 'reforms' haven't helped Wisconsin at all.

Living in Paris before Uber was pure taxi hell.  I don't care what the company does, greyball all you want. Because an incredibly rude, conniving taxi driver who could and would tac on extra to your faire for no apparent reason is the alternative.

Facilitating their subcontractors to avoid entrapment? Uber was actively encouraging their drivers (call them employees or subcontractors) to break the law. It's great for the drivers who weren't busted, but not so much for the sacrificial lambs who were not shielded. At the end of the day, Travis Kalanick broke the law. And he's now certainly rich enough that he will get away with it.

I deleted Uber's app two months ago when I discovered it was mining my iPhone data, then transmitting this personal intelligence, unrelated to rides, back to its mother ship. Grayball must be active in the U.S., or Uber would not cling so indignantly to its refusal to offer an industry-standard privacy option — allowing location sniffing ONLY when using the app. Now, it's choices are data snooping 24/7, or no location services all, which complicates rides. I moved on to Lyft.

Uber avoids being entrapped by disguised government agents who were acting to protect the interests of established taxi companies, and that gets headlined "deceives"?  Sound more like the people acting deceptively were the government agents. Uber acted to avoid them. Nothing deceptive there and Uber isn't required to inform the police state that it is acting to avoid its agents.

I try not to use Uber because of concerns about how they screen and regulate their drivers. Driving or riding in a car puts you at a higher risk for an accident/ injury/ death than many other things people are more afraid of (e.g. earthquakes, terrorism, getting struck by lightning). Taxis aren't perfect either but at least they screen their drivers more.

On the taxi side, many companies need to improve their customer service. In some cities, especially smaller ones with few taxi/ public transport options, the dispatcher is rude, rides are late if they arrive at all, and the cabs can be very dirty. An example of this is Stockton, CA. If anything, Uber gives taxis an incentive to improve their game. If companies were good to begin with, less people might be persuaded (despite lower prices) to use Uber.

For my part, I now use cabs that I get to know via a taxi company but who also have their own private service on the side, outside of Uber/ the taxi cab company etc. In other words, the driver owns their own car and has their own small business. This seems to achieve a happy medium between good service and good price. It doesn't work though for cities I do not frequent regularly where I don't know any drivers.

I do, too.  The driver takes dispatched calls from a company but also has his own business--on the meter.  I use him for airport and train station runs and for important medical appointments including a family member's day surgery that ran very late.  This guy picked us up in the very late evening.  His car is immaculate and, by the way, he is a legal resident from one of those countries included in the "Muslim ban."  Oops...

Wow, what a concept.  The cops aint your friends. It is not their job to be your friend. It's their job to put you in jail.  The cops may be the real enemies we all should be worried about. After reading this article I have gained a new and profound respect for Uber.  Seriously, what could possibly be gained by picking up a cop as a fare?  I know that if I were a driver I would not ever give a ride to someone I knew was a cop. I would rather pick up drug dealers and serial killers and would feel much safer doin so.   Seriously, what good could ever come from talking to a cop?
Taxi drivers ripped off customers, were rude and unreliable and were due a reality check. Will never take a taxi again. Only Uber.
If you concluded so much based on so little, your conclusions aren't worth the paper you might care to print them on.  Sorry.  Sounding authoritative isn't being authoritative.

I think Uber is what happens to super-capitalism when it goes wrong. There was a time when you did business with somebody because you found out from others they were relatively honest and honorable. Travis Kalanick is the poster-boy for the saw, "A fish rots from the head." He lives in a world of deception and deceit. Nobody turns their back on him to be sure. But you can also be sure that a lot business people admire his methods.

The real question remains: is this the future of business? I beg your pardon, but if it is, drop me off, Uber, at the next corner.
Think of Greyball as the same as deceiving the cops about when the Black Bloc are going to invade I-95 if you like.
RICO does not apply as no predicate offense has been committed.  The article pretty much grudgingly admits no offense of any kind has been committed.

You want to not move ahead with new technology and promote the use of taxis that passengers hate because of high rates, smelly, dirty cars and drivers, and drivers that mostly crude and harassing. That what you would promote?

What bothers me about Uber is that apparently anybody who drives a vehicle can work for them, even those with nefarious intentions, reported by a few victims but not given much press coverage. And what irritates me about cab drivers in big cities is that none that I encountered could barely speak English. Even parking lot attendants were of foreign origin with heavy accents. Don't Americans drive cabs anymore?

Unmentioned by a reflexive anti corporatist readership is that a very significant fraction of NYC's taxis are driver owned-- as many as a third or a half. These drivers paid dearly for their medallions and have seen the value of those medallions fall sharply in response to uber and other ride hailing services. The services should be regulated and the drivers should be vetted by some municipal authority and the regulating agencies should be funded by fees from the ride services. Where else do you allow yourself to be locked up at the mercy of a stranger for  prolonged periods? That might also restore some equity to thier competition with the profoundly harassed owner drivers of NY and other cities.
